description: Either a back-formation from or an apocopic form of scrummage, a variant of scrimmage.

entries.meaning: A tightly-packed and disorderly crowd of people.
examples: A scrum developed around the bar when free beer was announced.

entries.meaning: (Canada) A tightly packed group of reporters surrounding a person, usually a politician, asking for comments about an issue; an opportunity provided for a politician to be approached this way.
examples: A scrum formed around Scott Brison in the House of Commons lobby shortly after he announced his candidacy for the federal Liberal leadership.

entries.meaning: (rugby) In rugby union or rugby league, all the forwards joined together in an organised way.

(software engineering) In Agile software development (specifically Scrum or related methodologies), a daily meeting in which each developer describes what they have been doing, what they plan to do next, and any impediments to progress.

verbs.description: scrum (third-person singular simple present scrums, present participle scrumming, simple past and past participle scrummed)
